content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a moderately cautious and predictability-loving undergraduate student, I would choose B for most of the rounds to ensure a more stable income. However, to avoid being too predictable and potentially disadvantaging myself, I would mix up my choices occasionally by picking R as well. My strategy would be to play B in about 60 rounds (approximately 80% of the game) and switch to R for the remaining 15 rounds. This approach would allow me to secure a relatively high average income while still having some chances to maximize my earnings in case my opponent decides to switch strategies.

So, my choice in this situation would be to play B most of the time, with occasional switches to R: {B} (60 rounds) and {R} (15 rounds).
